awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type I: Brandeis University I-Corps Site Housed at the Hassenfeld Family Innovation Center
awd_abstract_narration:
This project establishes an I-Corps Site at Brandeis University, managed by the Office of Technology Licensing and housed at the Hassenfeld Family Innovation Center (HFIC). NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. The Site at Brandeis builds on resources that are central to the mission of HFIC, including: training, mentoring, and external engagement with industry.

This project utilizes a modest amount of funding ($ 237,050 over five years) to establish an I-Corps Site that will serve at least 15 commercialization teams each year. All of the elements for a successful proposal and project are in place. The institution has a track record for commercialization. They have interacted with the regional I-Corps Node and understand the I-Corps training process. There is an established pipeline of teams and there is a specific plan for recruiting underrepresented teams and for mentoring those teams through the commercialization processes.

This projects is likely to not only influence the culture of this institution but also impact the commercialization ecosystem in their geographical region.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of the I-Corps program at Brandeis University are marked by increased entrepreneurial success, refined technology commercialization strategies, and a greater interdisciplinary innovation ecosystem. Throughout the program, the Brandeis I-Corps site enabled:

  • Stronger cross-sector collaborations resulting in multidisciplinary teams tackling complex challenges.

  • Increased student (undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral) participation in entrepreneurial activities, bridging business, social policy, and scientific research.

  • Enhanced opportunities for students to engage in business development roles within research-driven ventures.

  • Greater integration of I-Corps with existing seed fund programs, providing multiple pathways for researchers to commercialize their work.

  • More impactful innovations emerging from Brandeis, driven by collaboration across disciplines, backgrounds, and cultures.

  • Refined technology commercialization strategies through data-driven patent prosecution decisions for Brandeis technologies, directly contributing to strategic investment. 

The program connected teams with experienced entrepreneurs, business experts, and venture capitalists who offer advice, feedback, and strategic direction. This mentorship helped participants navigate the challenges of building a business, from refining their value propositions to identifying market fit and securing initial funding. 

The program also provided participants with needed skills to succeed either as startup entrepreneurs or be work-ready in the technology development industry and for success in deep tech careers. The training helped STEM researchers and business students to:

  • Gain a first-hand experiential exposure to the commercialization and business creation process. These skills helped to expand their career prospects adding a differentiator to those entering the job market.

  • Understand different funding mechanisms and develop skills which allow them to locate and successfully utilize government, private, and industry funding opportunities.

  • Develop soft skills and competencies such as networking, effective communication, building and maintaining relationships, resourcefulness, and resilience which enable participants to take ownership of their own career and pursue opportunities that support their personal and professional growth.

  • Benefit from cross-boundary collaboration and teamwork. Participants in our I-Corps program experience collaborating with team members across disciplines, a critical skill that participants will need in their future academic or industry careers.

The Brandeis I-Corps site led 11 cohorts between 2017 and 2024. In all, 64 teams with a total of 216 individual team members participated in the training sessions. A diversity of projects ranged from those that prevent/treat disease, protect the environment, improve educational technology and provide novel nutraceutical ingredients. From these 11 I-Corps cohorts there have been 14 startups formed and they have collectively raised $2.62M in grant or seed funding. We expect the impact to exponentially grow as the program continues.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2025
Modified by: Rebecca Menapace

por.por_txt_cntn:
The outcomes of the I-Corps program at Brandeis University are marked by increased entrepreneurial success, refined technology commercialization strategies, and a greater interdisciplinary innovation ecosystem. Throughout the program, the Brandeis I-Corps site enabled:




Stronger cross-sector collaborations resulting in multidisciplinary teams tackling complex challenges.




Increased student (undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral) participation in entrepreneurial activities, bridging business, social policy, and scientific research.




Enhanced opportunities for students to engage in business development roles within research-driven ventures.




Greater integration of I-Corps with existing seed fund programs, providing multiple pathways for researchers to commercialize their work.




More impactful innovations emerging from Brandeis, driven by collaboration across disciplines, backgrounds, and cultures.




Refined technology commercialization strategies through data-driven patent prosecution decisions for Brandeis technologies, directly contributing to strategic investment.




The program connected teams with experienced entrepreneurs, business experts, and venture capitalists who offer advice, feedback, and strategic direction. This mentorship helped participants navigate the challenges of building a business, from refining their value propositions to identifying market fit and securing initial funding.


The program also provided participants with needed skills to succeed either as startup entrepreneurs or be work-ready in the technology development industry and for success in deep tech careers. The training helped STEM researchers and business students to:




Gain a first-hand experiential exposure to the commercialization and business creation process. These skills helped to expand their career prospects adding a differentiator to those entering the job market.




Understand different funding mechanisms and develop skills which allow them to locate and successfully utilize government, private, and industry funding opportunities.




Develop soft skills and competencies such as networking, effective communication, building and maintaining relationships, resourcefulness, and resilience which enable participants to take ownership of their own career and pursue opportunities that support their personal and professional growth.




Benefit from cross-boundary collaboration and teamwork. Participants in our I-Corps program experience collaborating with team members across disciplines, a critical skill that participants will need in their future academic or industry careers.




The Brandeis I-Corps site led 11 cohorts between 2017 and 2024. In all, 64 teams with a total of 216 individual team members participated in the training sessions. A diversity of projects ranged from those that prevent/treat disease, protect the environment, improve educational technology and provide novel nutraceutical ingredients. From these 11 I-Corps cohorts there have been 14 startups formed and they have collectively raised $2.62M in grant or seed funding. We expect the impact to exponentially grow as the program continues.
